questions.text: A patient presented with a fall on an outstretched hand. On X-ray, a fracture of the base of the 1st metacarpal bone was seen. This type of fracture is also known as: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bennett’s fracture

 

The fracture described in the question is a fracture of the base of the first metacarpal bone, which is characteristic of a Bennett's fracture. Bennett's fracture is an intra-articular fracture of the base of the first metacarpal, which extends into the carpometacarpal (CMC) joint. This type of fracture usually results from a force applied to the thumb during a fall on an outstretched hand.

 

The fracture typically results in a dislocation of the metacarpal from the trapezium due to the pull of the abductor pollicis longus muscle. On an X-ray, this fracture often appears as an oblique break at the base of the metacarpal, with a small fragment remaining attached to the trapezium.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Monteggia fracture: This involves a fracture of the proximal third of the ulna with dislocation of the head of the radius. It does not involve the first metacarpal and thus is not the correct answer.

 

Option C. Colle’s fracture: This is a distal radius fracture with dorsal angulation, typically resulting from a fall on an outstretched hand. It does not involve the first metacarpal, so this option is incorrect.

 

Option D. Smith’s fracture: This is also a distal radius fracture but with volar angulation. Similar to Colle’s fracture, it does not involve the first metacarpal, making it incorrect for this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bennett's fracture is an intra-articular fracture at the base of the first metacarpal bone, commonly caused by a fall on an outstretched hand. It is important to recognize this fracture due to its involvement with the CMC joint and potential for dislocation.

questions.text: Graft from identical twin is called: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Isograft

 

An isograft is a type of graft where the donor and the recipient are genetically identical individuals, such as identical twins. This type of graft has the lowest risk of rejection because the donor and recipient have the same genetic makeup, which means their tissues are immunologically compatible.

 

Types of Grafts:

 

Option A. Allograft:

 

  • Definition: A graft where the donor and recipient are of the same species but have different genotypes.
  • Examples: Organ transplants between two different individuals (e.g., kidney transplant from one person to another non-twin individual).

 

Option B. Autograft:

 

  • Definition: A graft where the donor and recipient are the same person.
  • Examples: Skin grafts taken from one part of the body and transplanted to another part of the same individual's body.

 

Option C. Isograft:

 

  • Definition: A graft between two individuals who are genetically identical, such as identical twins.
  • Examples: Organ or tissue transplants between identical twins.

 

Option D. Xenograft:

 

  • Definition: A graft where the donor and recipient are of different species.
  • Examples: Transplantation of animal tissues or organs into humans, such as pig heart valves used in human heart surgery.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Autografts are grafts in which both the donor and the recipient are the same person.
  • Isografts are grafts that occur between donors and recipients who share the same genotype. An isograft is a graft from an identical twin
  • Allografts are those in which the donor and recipient are of the same species but of a different genotype.
  • Xenografts are those in which the donor and recipient are of different species.

questions.text: A patient presents with a seizure. On evaluation, urine osmolality is 1000 mOsm/Kg and serum osmolality is 270 mOsm/Kg. Which electrolyte abnormality can be expected in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hyponatremia

 

The patient's laboratory findings show high urine osmolality and low serum osmolality, which are indicative of a condition where the kidneys are concentrating urine despite low blood osmolality. This is characteristic of the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) secretion.

 

In SIADH, excessive release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) leads to water retention, dilutional hyponatremia (low serum sodium), and the production of concentrated urine (high urine osmolality). The body retains water, which dilutes the blood sodium levels but the kidneys continue to excrete sodium, resulting in a low serum osmolality.

 

Differential diagnosis - Cerebral Salt Wasting Syndrome (CSWS):

 

  • Fluid Status: Patients are hypovolemic, meaning there is a reduced volume of circulating fluid in the body.
  • Characteristics: It involves the loss of sodium from the body, which exceeds the loss of water, leading to hyponatremia and decreased blood volume. This condition is often associated with neurological disorders such as injuries or diseases affecting the brain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypernatremia: Hypernatremia refers to high sodium levels in the blood, which would typically be associated with high serum osmolality. This does not fit the patient's laboratory findings.

 

Option C. Hyperkalemia: Hyperkalemia is an elevated level of potassium in the blood and does not correlate with the osmolality findings presented.

 

Option D. Hypokalemia: Hypokalemia is a low potassium level in the blood and, while it can be associated with various conditions, it is not directly indicated by the osmolality findings described in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients presenting with low serum osmolality and high urine osmolality, SIADH is a likely diagnosis, and the primary electrolyte abnormality to expect is hyponatremia.

choices.text: She is susceptible to chicken pox
She is immune to chicken pox

questions.text: A pregnant woman residing in the same house as her niece, who has contracted Varicella, received a negative result in her test for serum antibodies against varicella. What implications can be drawn from this? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) She is susceptible to chicken pox

 

Anti-Varicella/Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV)/Chickenpox IgG; Varicella immunity test

 

  • Negative: Indicates no detectable Varicella IgG antibodies. A negative results indicate no current or previous infection with Varicella virus. Such individuals are presumed to be susceptible to primary infection.
  • Equivocal: Equivocal results are indeterminate. Patient may or may not have immunity to Varicella Virus. It is not acceptable proof of immunity.
  • Positive: Indicates evidence of Varicella IgG antibodies and suggests past or current infection with Varicella virus. Antibodies obtained via acquired immunity or immunization and probable protection from clinical infection. (Immunity).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. She is immune to zoster: Incorrect. Immunity to zoster (shingles) comes from having had a previous varicella (chicken pox) infection or vaccination. A negative antibody test indicates she has not had varicella.

 

Option B. She is susceptible to zoster: Incorrect. Susceptibility to zoster (shingles) typically arises from a reactivation of the varicella virus in individuals who have previously had chicken pox. A negative test means she has not had chicken pox, so she cannot develop zoster but is susceptible to chicken pox.

 

Option D. She is immune to chicken pox: Incorrect. A negative antibody test indicates she does not have immunity to chicken pox.
 

Educational Objective:

 

A negative test result for serum antibodies against varicella indicates that the individual is susceptible to chicken pox, as there are no detectable antibodies suggesting past infection or vaccination.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient on immunosuppressive therapy presents with cough, fever, and pneumonia. A biopsy reveals the cells shown in the image. Which organism is responsible for this finding? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CMV (Cytomegalovirus)

 

The image provided shows cells with the characteristic "owl eye" appearance, which is a classic histopathological finding in infections caused by Cytomegalovirus (CMV). CMV is a type of herpesvirus that can cause severe infections, especially in immunocompromised patients, such as those on immunosuppressive therapy.

 

The "owl eye" appearance refers to the large intranuclear inclusion bodies surrounded by a clear halo, resembling an owl's eye. This appearance is due to the replication of the virus within the nucleus of the infected cell, leading to the formation of these inclusion bodies. In CMV infections, both intranuclear and intracytoplasmic basophilic inclusions can be observed, which is a key diagnostic feature.

 

CMV commonly causes pneumonia in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV/AIDS, organ transplant recipients, or patients on immunosuppressive therapy. The virus can also cause other severe complications, including retinitis, colitis, and encephalitis.

 

Note – Ganciclovir - Preferred antiviral medication for treating CMV infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pox virus: Poxviruses, such as the variola virus (which causes smallpox), typically produce skin lesions and are not known for causing the "owl eye" appearance in cells. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

 

Option C. EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus): EBV is associated with conditions such as infectious mononucleosis and certain lymphomas, like Burkitt's lymphoma. It does not typically produce the "owl eye" inclusions seen in CMV infection, making this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Chickenpox (Varicella-Zoster Virus): Chickenpox, caused by the varicella-zoster virus, is characterized by vesicular skin lesions and does not produce the "owl eye" appearance in histological sections. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "owl eye" appearance of cells in a biopsy is a hallmark of Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection, particularly in immunocompromised patients. This feature is crucial for diagnosing CMV-related complications, such as CMV pneumonia.

questions.text: A patient is presenting with a staggering gait and nystagmus (Rhomberg sign +ve) after a road traffic accident. Which lobe of cerebellum is affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Flocculonodular

 

The symptoms described—staggering gait, nystagmus, and a positive Rhomberg sign—are indicative of damage to the cerebellum, specifically the flocculonodular lobe. The flocculonodular lobe is responsible for maintaining balance, posture, and controlling the vestibulo-ocular reflex, which is crucial for stabilizing vision during head movements. The presence of nystagmus (involuntary eye movements) suggests a disturbance in the vestibulo-ocular reflex, pointing towards a lesion in the flocculonodular lobe. This part of the cerebellum is particularly involved in coordinating the balance and equilibrium of the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dentate: The dentate nucleus is involved in the planning and execution of fine motor movements rather than the maintenance of balance and posture.

 

Option C. Anterior lobe: The anterior lobe of the cerebellum is primarily associated with coordinating limb movements and maintaining muscle tone.

 

Option D. Vermis: The vermis is responsible for controlling the body's midline movements, such as the trunk and head.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The flocculonodular lobe of the cerebellum is crucial for maintaining balance, posture, and controlling the vestibulo-ocular reflex. Damage to this area can lead to symptoms such as a staggering gait, nystagmus, and balance issues, as seen in the case of cerebellar ataxia following trauma.

questions.text: Which of the following antidiabetic drugs is preferred in a patient with heart and kidney disease? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) SGLT-2 inhibitors

 

Explanation:

 

SGLT-2 inhibitors (e.g., dapagliflozin, empagliflozin, canagliflozin) are the preferred first-line agents in diabetic patients with heart and kidney disease because they:

 

  • Reduce major adverse cardiovascular events
  • Decrease heart failure hospitalizations
  • Slow progression of diabetic kidney disease
  • Reduce proteinuria and lower blood pressure
  • Provide cardio-protection independent of glucose control

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Biguanides (Metformin): While first-line for type 2 diabetes, it does not provide cardiovascular benefits and requires caution in kidney disease due to the risk of lactic acidosis

 

Option B. GLP-1 receptor agonists: While cardioprotective, they do not provide as strong heart failure or renal benefits as SGLT-2 inhibitors

 

Option D. Sulfonylureas: Not preferred because:

 

  • High risk of hypoglycemia, especially in renal disease
  • No proven cardiovascular benefits
  • Possible increased cardiovascular risk with certain sulfonylureas

 

Educational Objective:

 

SGLT-2 inhibitors are the preferred antidiabetic agents in patients with heart failure and chronic kidney disease (CKD) due to their proven cardiovascular and renal benefits.

questions.text: Identify the investigation shown. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PET

 

The image provided shows a comparison between three types of imaging modalities: PET, CT, and PET-CT. PET (Positron Emission Tomography) is a nuclear medicine functional imaging technique used to observe metabolic processes in the body. In this case, the PET scan highlights areas of the body where the radioactive glucose analog 18F-FDG has been absorbed, typically areas with high glucose metabolism such as tumors.

 

The combined PET-CT image integrates the metabolic information from the PET scan with the anatomical detail provided by the CT scan, which allows for precise localization of the metabolic activity within the body's structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. USG: Ultrasound (USG) uses sound waves to create images of the inside of the body. It does not produce the type of image shown in this question.

 

Option B. MRI: Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) uses strong magnetic fields and radio waves to produce detailed images of the body's internal structures. The images from MRI are different from those of PET scans, which focus on metabolic activity.

 

Option D. X-ray: X-rays provide images based on the absorption of X-ray photons by different tissues, primarily used to visualize bone structures. The image shown is not an X-ray, as it does not display the typical bone-focused detail of X-ray imaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The investigation shown in the image is a PET scan (and PET-CT), which highlights areas of high metabolic activity, commonly used for detecting cancer.

choices.text: Herpes simplex virus
Ebstein Barr virus

questions.text: A patient underwent a renal transplant following which he developed an infection that had owl eye inclusions. What is the likely cause of the finding? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cytomegalovirus

 

The presence of owl eye inclusions in a patient with a history of immunosuppression (such as following a renal transplant) is highly suggestive of cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection.

 

Cytomegalovirus (CMV):

 

  • Pathology: CMV is a member of the herpesvirus family and is a common cause of infection in immunocompromised individuals. The virus causes the formation of characteristic intranuclear inclusions that resemble owl's eyes.
  • Clinical Features: Patients may present with fever, fatigue, and signs of organ-specific involvement, such as pneumonitis, hepatitis, or retinitis, depending on the site of infection.
  • Histopathology: The characteristic finding on histopathology is the presence of large cells with basophilic intranuclear inclusions surrounded by a clear halo, giving the appearance of owl's eyes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Herpes simplex virus: Typically causes vesicular lesions and does not produce owl eye inclusions.

 

Option B. Epstein Barr virus: Associated with infectious mononucleosis and various lymphoproliferative disorders, not typically owl eye inclusions.

 

Option D. HIV: Causes immunosuppression but does not produce characteristic owl eye inclusions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Owl eye inclusions seen in immunocompromised patients, especially post-transplant, are indicative of cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection.

choices.text: Start breastfeeding as soon as possible
Clear eyes with a sterile swab
Bath to newborn with warm water

questions.text: A mother delivers in a rural area under the guidance of a skilled birth attendant. Incorrect regarding the care provided by the skilled birth attendant is: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Bath to newborn with warm water

 

Bathing a newborn immediately after birth is not recommended as it can cause rapid heat loss and hypothermia in the infant. Instead, after delivery, the newborn should be wiped clean with a sterile cloth and wrapped warmly without giving a bath. The bath can be delayed until at least 24 hours after birth or later when the baby’s body temperature has stabilized, especially in settings without advanced care facilities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start breastfeeding as soon as possible: It is recommended to initiate breastfeeding immediately after birth, ideally within the first hour for vaginal deliveries and within 4 hours for cesarean sections. Early breastfeeding provides the newborn with essential nutrients and antibodies and helps stimulate milk production.

 

Option B. Clear eyes with a sterile swab: Clearing the eyes of a newborn with a sterile swab is correct. If needed, antiseptic solutions like 1% silver nitrate or 1% tetracycline ointment can be used to prevent ophthalmia neonatorum, an eye infection that can occur in newborns.

 

Option D. Cover baby’s head and body: Covering the baby’s head and body immediately after birth is essential to prevent heat loss. Newborns lose up to 75% of their body heat through the head, making it crucial to keep the baby warm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Newborns should not be bathed immediately after birth to prevent hypothermia; instead, they should be wiped clean and kept warm by wrapping them appropriately.

choices.text: Moderate or regular exercise for 30 min
Pharmacological intervention with proton pump inhibitors

questions.text: Which of the following measures are associated with an increased life span? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decreasing calorie intake by 30 percent

 

Decreasing calorie intake by 30 percent will increase lifespan.

 

Caloric restriction reduces the severity of oxidative damage as well as the resulting decline in function. It lowers the steady-state concentrations of oxidative damage products in proteins, DNA, and lipids. This is due to a decrease in mitochondrial superoxide anion and hydrogen peroxide production and an increase in antioxidant production. Caloric restriction slows the rate of energy metabolism overall.

 

Caloric restriction postpones the onset of age-related diseases like cancer (including lymphomas, breast and prostate cancers), nephropathy, and cataracts. Caloric restriction also reduces the onset of diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and the development of autoimmune diseases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Moderate or regular exercise for 30 min: While exercise has numerous health benefits and can improve quality of life and reduce the risk of chronic diseases, it has not been directly linked to the same extent of lifespan extension as caloric restriction in scientific studies.

 

Option B. Decrease stress: Reducing stress can improve health outcomes and prevent stress-related diseases, but specific lifespan extension evidence is less robust compared to caloric restriction.

 

Option D. Pharmacological intervention with proton pump inhibitors: Proton pump inhibitors are used to treat gastrointestinal conditions like acid reflux and ulcers. They are not associated with increased lifespan and may have adverse effects if used long-term.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Caloric restriction, by decreasing calorie intake by 30 percent, is associated with an increased lifespan and the postponement of age-related diseases. It reduces oxidative damage, slows metabolism, and mitigates the onset of various chronic conditions.

questions.text: In the cadaveric specimen shown, which nerve is marked by the black arrow? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Medial pectoral nerve

 

The nerve marked in the image is the medial pectoral nerve. This nerve specifically pierces the pectoralis minor muscle. In the pectoral region, the large muscle visible is the pectoralis major, and when this muscle is cut, the pectoralis minor is seen underneath. The medial pectoral nerve is responsible for innervating both the pectoralis minor and major muscles. The distinguishing feature of this nerve is its penetration through the pectoralis minor muscle, making it identifiable in anatomical images.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thoracodorsal nerve: This nerve supplies the latissimus dorsi muscle and does not have any direct association with the pectoralis muscles or the clavipectoral fascia, making it an incorrect choice in this context.

 

Option B. Lateral pectoral nerve: The lateral pectoral nerve primarily supplies the pectoralis major muscle and pierces the clavipectoral fascia between the clavicle and the pectoralis minor, not the muscle itself. Thus, it is not the nerve marked in the image.

 

Option D. Long thoracic nerve: This nerve supplies the serratus anterior muscle, located along the lateral thoracic wall, and does not pierce the pectoralis minor, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The medial pectoral nerve is the nerve that pierces the pectoralis minor muscle and also provides innervation to the pectoralis major.

choices.text: Thin endometrium with no adnexal mass
Empty uterus with adnexal mass and fluid in pelvis

questions.text: A 25-year-old G2 presents with delayed menstrual cycles, mild abdominal pain, and vaginal bleeding. A urine pregnancy test is positive. What are the ultrasound features suggestive of an ectopic pregnancy? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Empty uterus with adnexal mass and fluid in pelvis

 

In ectopic pregnancy, transvaginal ultrasound is the first-line investigation. The most characteristic finding is an empty uterine cavity with a mass in the adnexa  and fluid collection in the pelvis. The fluid represents blood from either tubal abortion or rupture, which typically collects in the pouch of Douglas behind the uterus. These findings together strongly suggest an ectopic pregnancy.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Thin endometrium with no adnexal mass: Incorrect because in ectopic pregnancy, the presence of an adnexal mass is a key diagnostic feature. Without an adnexal mass, the diagnosis is incomplete.

 

Option C. Intra uterine gestational sac: Incorrect as this finding indicates a normal intrauterine pregnancy, not an ectopic pregnancy.

 

Option D. Thick endometrium: Incorrect because this finding alone is nonspecific and can be seen in various conditions. It does not help diagnose ectopic pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The classic ultrasound findings in ectopic pregnancy are:

 

1. Empty uterine cavity

 

2. Adnexal mass (Bagel sign/ Blob sign)

 

3. Gestational sac with yolk sav/ fetal pole in the adnexa

 

4. Ring of fire on Doppler

 

 

5. Free fluid in the pelvis (representing blood from abortion or rupture)

questions.text: A 42-year-old patient with HIV and a CD4 count of 50 cells/µL presents with severe headache, altered mental status, and impaired consciousness. CSF examination using India ink preparation reveals encapsulated yeast cells. Which organism is most likely responsible? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cryptococcus neoformans

 

This is a classic presentation of cryptococcal meningitis in an HIV patient with:

 

  • Advanced HIV (CD4 count <50 cells/µL)
  • Neurological symptoms (headache, altered mental status)
  • Positive India ink preparation showing encapsulated yeast cells
  • CSF involvement

 

Cryptococcus neoformans is an encapsulated yeast that commonly causes meningitis in immunocompromised patients, particularly those with HIV/AIDS and CD4 counts below 100 cells/µL.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candida albicans: Rarely causes meningitis, and when it does, it's not visualized with India ink preparation.

 

Option B. Histoplasma capsulatum: Though it can cause systemic infection in HIV patients, it's not typically seen as encapsulated yeast in CSF and isn't visualized with India ink.

 

Option D. Candida tropicalis: Like C. albicans, it rarely causes meningitis and isn't visualized with India ink preparation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cryptococcus neoformans as the cause of meningitis in HIV patients with low CD4 counts, diagnosed by India ink preparation showing encapsulated yeasts in CSF.

questions.text: Diagnose the image seen in a 10-year-old child. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Herbert pits

 

Herbert pits are depressions seen on the cornea, typically found in patients with trachoma, a chronic infectious disease caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. These pits are formed when the follicles, which are lymphocyte aggregates, present at the limbus (called Herbert follicles) rupture or degenerate, leaving behind characteristic pits. This condition is commonly seen in individuals with trachoma who have chronic eye rubbing due to persistent irritation.

 

Other findings of trachoma are –

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Horner Trantas spots: These are white, elevated, gelatinous spots seen at the limbus, usually associated with vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC), an allergic condition of the eye. They are composed of eosinophils and epithelial cells and are not associated with depressions on the cornea.

 

 

Other findings of VKC are –

 

 

Giant papillae, also known as the cobblestone appearance

 

 

Ropey discharge (Maxwell-Leon sign)

 

Option C. Pannus: Pannus is the growth of abnormal blood vessels into the cornea, often accompanied by fibrovascular tissue. This condition is typically seen in trachoma but presents as vascularization rather than depressions.

 

 

Option D. Corneal dystrophy: This refers to a group of genetic disorders that cause the accumulation of abnormal material in the cornea. Corneal dystrophies present with clouding, swelling, or other structural changes in the cornea, not with pits or depressions.

 

 

Educational Objective:


Herbert pits are characteristic depressions found in the cornea due to the rupture of follicles, commonly seen in trachoma.

questions.text: A tissue sample shows significant cellular damage. Which of the following changes is most indicative of irreversible cell injury in the sample? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amorphous density of mitochondria

 

Amorphous densities in mitochondria are characteristic features of irreversible cell injury. These densities represent calcium phosphate deposits within damaged mitochondria, which occur as the mitochondrial membrane becomes increasingly permeable during severe cell injury. When mitochondria are severely damaged, they can no longer maintain calcium homeostasis, leading to calcium influx and the formation of these dense deposits. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cellular swelling: This is an early change that can be seen in both reversible and irreversible cell injury. It occurs due to the failure of the sodium-potassium pump resulting in sodium accumulation within the cell, followed by water influx. Since this is a nonspecific finding that can be present in both reversible and irreversible injury, it's not the most indicative of irreversible damage.

 

Option B. Bleb formation: Blebs are outpouchings of the plasma membrane that form due to focal weakening of the cytoskeleton. Like cellular swelling, bleb formation can be seen in both reversible and irreversible cell injury, so it's not specifically indicative of irreversible damage.

 

Option D. Cytoplasmic vacuolation: Vacuoles can form in the cytoplasm during cell injury due to dilation of the endoplasmic reticulum or increased autophagy. This change is commonly seen in reversible cell injury and is therefore not the most reliable indicator of irreversible damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of amorphous densities in mitochondria is a morphological feature that indicates irreversible cell injury, distinguishing it from changes that can be seen in both reversible and irreversible injury such as cellular swelling, bleb formation, and cytoplasmic vacuolation.

choices.text: Patient must be started on anti-gas gangrene serum therapy
It is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection

questions.text: A 67 yrs. old male patient visits the emergency department due to rapidly worsening pain and swelling in the genital and perianal regions, with signs of necrotizing infection as shown below upon examination, the patient has a history of alcohol abuse and poorly controlled diabetes, and laboratory tests reveal leukocytosis and elevated blood glucose levels. What is the accurate statement about the condition presented by the patient?  (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. It is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection

 

  • The image and clinical scenario suggest Fournier's gangrene, which is a mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection and a surgical emergency.
  • Fournier's gangrene is a rapidly progressive infection of the genitalia and perineum caused by mixed bacterial flora, often associated with diabetes, cancer, malnutrition, recent urogenital or colorectal instrumentation, or trauma.
  • Symptoms of Fournier's gangrene include erythema, swelling, pain, and blister formation with ultimately foul-smelling necrotic lesions.
  • Correct. Fournier's gangrene involves a mixed infection with both aerobic (oxygen-using) and anaerobic (not oxygen-using) bacteria. The presence of multiple bacterial types contributes to the rapid progression and severity of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Patient must be started on anti-gas gangrene serum therapy: Incorrect. Anti-gas gangrene serum therapy is typically used for the treatment of gas gangrene caused by the bacterium Clostridium perfringens. While C. perfringens can sometimes be a part of the mixed bacterial flora in Fournier's gangrene, the condition itself is not specifically gas gangrene, and thus anti-gas gangrene serum therapy is not the primary treatment.

 

Option C. Bilateral orchidectomy is generally performed: Incorrect. A bilateral orchidectomy, or the removal of both testes, is not a standard treatment for Fournier's gangrene. Testes are typically spared in Fournier’s gangrene.

 

Option D. Compulsory urinary diversion is performed: Incorrect. While urinary diversion might be considered in some cases where the urethra is compromised or if there's significant involvement of the urogenital structures, it's not a compulsory or routine part of the management of Fournier's gangrene.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fournier's gangrene is a surgical emergency characterized by a mixed aerobic and anaerobic bacterial infection of the genital and perianal regions, often associated with underlying conditions like diabetes and malnutrition.
  • It requires prompt surgical debridement and broad-spectrum antibiotics.

questions.text: A photographer who recently returned from Africa presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, and hemorrhagic manifestations. He died despite treatment, and an autopsy revealed intranuclear Torres bodies in the liver. Which of the following vaccines could have prevented it? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 17D

 

The above clinical vignette is suggestive of yellow fever and the use of 17D vaccine could have prevented this.

 

17D vaccine is a live-attenuated vaccine administered through the subcutaneous route. It is contraindicated in infants less than 9 months of age, in pregnancy, and in individuals with egg allergy.

 

Yellow fever is caused by flavivirus and is endemic to certain parts of Africa and America. It occurs in two patterns: the urban cycle and the sylvatic cycle. Aedes aegypti is the vector in the urban cycle, while Aedes africanus is responsible for transmission in the sylvatic cycle.

 

Patients present with acute onset fever, headache, and vomiting. Jaundice and hemorrhagic manifestations can also be present. Ultimately, hepatic or renal failure can result in death.

 

Torres bodies are intranuclear eosinophilic inclusion bodies in hepatocytes. These are rarely seen in yellow fever. To prevent the establishment of the disease in India, strict vaccination and quarantine protocols for travelers from endemic areas are enforced.

 

Other options:

 

Option B: Nakayama vaccine is used for immunization against Japanese encephalitis. Culex tritaeniorhynchus is the principal vector. There is a sudden onset of fever and vomiting, which later progresses to encephalitis. In India, it was first reported in Vellore and continues to be active in the country.

 

Option C. Weigl's vaccine is the earliest used vaccine against epidemic typhus caused by Rickettsia prowazekii. The main foci of the disease are Europe, Africa, South America, and Asia. Kashmir is the endemic spot in India. Pediculus humans corporis (human body louse) is the vector. Symptoms include fever and chills. A characteristic rash on the trunk and limbs, sparing the face, palms, and soles, may also be seen.

 

Option D. Jeryl-Lynn strain of the mumps virus is used against the disease as a live-attenuated vaccine. It is contraindicated in pregnancy and individuals allergic to eggs. Mumps present as parotid swelling associated with fever and tenderness.

 

Educational Objective

 

The 17D vaccine could have prevented the yellow fever that led to the photographer's severe symptoms and death. This highlights the importance of appropriate vaccination before traveling to areas where yellow fever is endemic.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding non-competitive inhibition?  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Constant Km and decreased Vmax

 

Explanation:

 

Noncompetitive inhibition has constant Km and decreased Vmax.

 

More complex noncompetitive inhibition occurs when binding of the inhibitor does affect the apparent affinity of the enzyme for substrate, causing the lines to intercept in either the third or fourth quadrants of a double-reciprocal plot.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A man exposes his genitalia to a female passerby on the road. This method of deriving sexual gratification by observing the people that look at him nude is best described as? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Exhibitionism

 

The given history is suggestive of exhibitionism. Exhibitionism is a condition where an individual derives sexual gratification by exposing their genitalia to unsuspecting people and observing their reactions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Voyeurism

 

  • Definition: Sexual gratification by watching others, typically women, engaged in sexual activity or in a state of undress. The person engaging in this behavior is known as a "peeping tom."
  • Punishment: Punishable under Section 354(C) IPC.

 

Option B. Fetishism

 

  • Definition: Sexual arousal and gratification are achieved through objects or specific body parts, such as footwear, undergarments, etc., often belonging to the opposite sex.

 

Option D. Masochism

 

  • Definition: Sexual gratification is obtained through experiencing pain or humiliation inflicted upon oneself.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Free iron is toxic for the cells
Iron will be stored in the form of transferrin
Iron is transported via Apoferritin in the blood
Hepcidin enhances iron transport through Ferroportin

questions.text: Which one of the following is correct about iron transport? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Free iron is toxic for the cells

 

Free iron in the body is highly reactive and can catalyze the formation of free radicals, leading to oxidative stress and cellular damage. This is why iron is typically bound to proteins such as transferrin in the blood and ferritin within cells to prevent free iron from causing harm. The body has mechanisms to tightly regulate iron levels to avoid toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Iron will be stored in the form of transferrin: This statement is incorrect. Transferrin is a transport protein that carries iron in the bloodstream. Iron is stored in the body as ferritin or hemosiderin, not transferrin.

 

Option C. Iron is transported via Apoferritin in the blood: This is incorrect. Apoferritin binds iron to form ferritin, which is used for storage, not transport. Iron transport in the blood is mainly handled by transferrin.

 

Option D. Hepcidin enhances iron transport through Ferroportin: This is incorrect. Hepcidin actually inhibits iron transport by binding to ferroportin, leading to its degradation. This reduces the amount of iron released into the bloodstream from cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Free iron is toxic to cells due to its ability to generate reactive oxygen species, which can cause significant cellular damage.

questions.text: Which agency offers seeds and manure as part of applied nutrition programs in schools? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) UNICEF

 

UNICEF

 

Applied Nutrition Program

 

  • UNICEF promoted the scheme by supplying basic equipment for production and training while FAO and WHO were involved in providing technical advice
  • UNICEF provided seeds, manure and water supply equipment for developing School gardens, to be utilized in school feeding programs

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CARE:  - ‘Cooperative for Assistance and Relief Everywhere’ supports following project:

 

  • Integrated Nutrition and Health Project
  • Better Health and Nutrition Project
  • Anaemia Control Project
  • Improving Women's Health Project
  • Improved Health Care for Adolescent Girl's Project
  • Child Survival Project
  • Improving Women's Reproductive Health and Family Spacing Project
  • Konkan Integrate Development Project

 

Option B. UNDP:  The basic objective of the UNDP is to help poorer nations develop their human and natural resources more fully. The UNDP projects cover virtually every economic and social sector - agriculture, industry, education and science, health, social welfare, etc.

 

Option D. WHO:  World Health Organization aims at the attainment of the highest level of health by all people, which helps them to lead a socially and economically productive life.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

UNICEF provides seeds, manure, and water supply equipment as part of its Applied Nutrition Program to develop school gardens, which are used in school feeding programs to improve children's nutrition.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman came to the OPD with a diagnosis of advanced cervical cancer. She has a 14-year-old daughter. What advice would you give for her daughter? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Advise HPV vaccine

 

The patient's 14-year-old daughter should be advised to take the HPV vaccine.

 

Screening CA cervix begins at the age of 25 years.

 

HPV vaccine

 

  • Contains recombinant VLP (L1 synthetic capsid protein)
  • Types –
    • Cervarix: Bivalent (16,18)
    • Gardasil: Quadrivalent (6,11,16,18)
    • Gardasil 9: Nonavalent (6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58)
    • Dosing as per IAP:
      • Girls 9 to 14 years: 2 doses
      • > 15 years: 3 doses

 

On June 1, 2023 there will be the launch of Indian indigenous vaccine called Cervavac , quadrivalent vaccine produce by Serum Institute of India (6, 11, 16, 18).

 

WHO’s Safe Advisory Group (SAGE) in 2021 advised regarding updating dose schedules for HPV as follows:

 

  • One or two-dose schedule for the primary target of girls aged 9-14
  • One or two-dose schedule for young women aged 15-20
  • Two doses with a 6-month interval for women older than 21

 

Immunocompromised individuals, including those with HIV, should receive three doses if feasible, and if not at least two doses. There is limited evidence regarding the efficacy of a single dose in this group.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Screen for BRCA mutation: BRCA mutation causes breast cancer, ovarian cancer, endometrial cancer

 

Option C. Screen for PTEN mutation: PTEN mutation (chromosome 10) causes Cowden syndrome, has 20-30% risk of developing endometrial cancer.

 

Option D. Perform cervical biopsy: Cervical biopsy is not indicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The HPV vaccine is essential for preventing cervical cancer and should be administered to girls aged 9 to 14 years, ideally before the onset of sexual activity.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with the clinical condition shown in the image? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Malignant Melanoma

 

The given image showing a benign proliferation of Nevus (type of melanocytes) in a child points to diagnosis of congenital melanocytic nevus.

 

Characteristics of Congenital Melanocytic Nevus

 

  • Seen since birth
  • Black-colored palpable lesion with well-defined borders
  • Surface is rough, hair
  • If > 20cm – giant congenital melanocytic nevus
  • Risk of melanoma is present

 

Congenital melanocytic nevi (CMN) can be associated with various complications, some of which include:

 

  1. Risk of Melanoma: Individuals with CMN have an increased risk of developing melanoma, a type of skin cancer. This risk is particularly higher in cases of giant congenital melanocytic nevi (GCMN)
  2. Neurocutaneous Melanosis: CMN can be linked to neurocutaneous melanosis, a condition where melanocytes are found in the central nervous system. This condition can lead to neurological issues and requires careful monitoring and management
  3. Proliferative Nodules: In some cases, CMN may develop proliferative nodules, which are areas of increased pigmentation and growth within the nevus. These nodules should be evaluated by a healthcare professional to rule out malignancy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cataract: This is characterized by clouding of the lens within the eye, leading to a decrease in vision. It is not related to skin lesions such as a congenital melanocytic nevus.

 

Option B: Sturge-Weber Syndrome (SWS) often leads to secondary glaucoma due to vascular malformations affecting eye drainage, with facial involvement increasing the risk.

 

SWS presents clinically as Port wine stain.

 

Port wine stain

 

  • Features: Also known as nevus flammeus, it is a capillary malformation that presents as a flat, pink, red, or purplish mark. It remains unchanged throughout life and can be anywhere on the body but is often seen on the face as shown below in the image.

 

 

Managing SWS-related glaucoma requires a multidisciplinary approach and regular eye exams for early detection and vision preservation.

 

Option D. Basal cell carcinoma: This is the most common form of skin cancer, often associated with long-term sun exposure. It typically appears as a raised, pearly bump and does not usually develop from congenital melanocytic nevi.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Congenital melanocytic nevi, especially larger ones, carry an increased risk for the development of malignant melanoma.
  • Monitoring and possibly biopsy of suspicious changes within these nevi are important for early detection of malignant transformation.

 

References: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition page number 75.9 to 75.14 73.2, 73.3

questions.text: A baby who can ride a tricycle, can walk alternate steps on stairs, he cannot do hopping. What is the age of the baby? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3.5 years

 

A 3-year-old child can typically ride a tricycle and walk up stairs with alternate feet. The ability to ride a tricycle is usually developed around the age of 3, as "tri" refers to three, indicating this milestone. Walking up stairs with alternate feet is another skill that a 3-year-old can manage. However, hopping on one foot usually develops around the age of 4. Since the child in question cannot hop yet, it indicates the child is likely not yet 4 years old. Therefore, the best answer is 3.5 years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A child who can ride a tricycle and walk up stairs with alternate feet but cannot hop is typically around 3.5 years old.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl went out playing. After coming home, she looked confused. Parents brought her to the hospital, and on examination, she looked irritable and has not passed urine since morning. Her friends said she had something while playing. Which of the following is the likely intoxication and the correct antidote? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Datura; Physostigmine

 

The clinical presentation suggests anticholinergic toxicity, characterized by confusion, irritability, and urinary retention. Datura, commonly known as jimsonweed or thorn apple, contains tropane alkaloids like atropine, scopolamine, and hyoscyamine, which cause anticholinergic symptoms.

 

Anticholinergic toxicity manifests with:

 

  • Central nervous system effects: confusion, hallucinations, irritability
  • Peripheral effects: dry mouth, urinary retention, constipation, tachycardia, hyperthermia

 

The appropriate antidote for anticholinergic toxicity is a cholinergic drug like physostigmine, which increases the levels of acetylcholine by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Yellow oleander; Physostigmine: Yellow oleander poisoning involves cardiac glycosides similar to digoxin, which can cause bradycardia, hyperkalemia, and gastrointestinal symptoms. The antidote for oleander poisoning is Digibind, not physostigmine.

 

Option B. Datura; Digibind: While datura poisoning is correctly identified here, Digibind is the antidote for digoxin or digitalis toxicity, not anticholinergic toxicity caused by datura.

 

Option C. Yellow oleander; Digibind: This option correctly pairs yellow oleander poisoning with its antidote, Digibind. However, the clinical presentation does not fit yellow oleander poisoning, which typically involves bradycardia and gastrointestinal symptoms rather than confusion and urinary retention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Datura poisoning causes anticholinergic toxicity, characterized by confusion, urinary retention, and other anticholinergic symptoms. The antidote for such toxicity is physostigmine, a cholinergic agent that increases acetylcholine levels by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with an ulcerative lesion near the medial canthus of his eye, featuring pearly margins. Microscopic examination reveals a palisading arrangement of cells. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Basal cell carcinoma

 

This case presents classic features of basal cell carcinoma (BCC):

 

  • Most common malignancy of skin
  • Location above the line joining angle of mouth and ear lobe
  • Medial canthus involvement is common
  • Characteristic pearly white beaded borders

 

 

  • Locally invasive tumor, can undergo ulceration which are called as rodent ulcers with rolled out edges.

 

 

  • Surface shows telangiectasia
  • Histologically shows peripheral palisading pattern

 

 

Palisading granuloma

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Keratoacanthoma

 

  • Rapidly growing tumor with central keratotic plug
  • Dome-shaped lesion resembling molluscum

 

 

  • Self-limiting nature
  • Different clinical and histological appearance
  • No pearly margins

 

Option B. Melanocytic melanoma

 

  • Pigmented lesion with ABCDE features

 

 

  • Shows asymmetry, border irregularity
  • Colour variation and diameter >6mm
  • No pearly margins
  • Different histological pattern

 

 

Option C. Squamous cell carcinoma

 

  • Presents as papulosquamous lesion
  • Shows erythematous base with scaling

 

 

  • More aggressive behaviour
  • Histopathology shows keratin pearls but no palisading
  • Different clinical appearance

 

 

Educational Objective:


Basal cell carcinoma typically presents with pearly margins and palisading arrangement of cells on histology, commonly occurring above the line joining angle of mouth and ear lobe. It is a locally invasive tumor that rarely metastasizes.

questions.text: A young male came with GI complaints like malabsorption, diarrhea. Cutaneous examination noted itchy lesions on the skin with blistering. On histopathology, cryptitis and flattened villi were noted. His condition improved with a gluten-free diet. What is the specific antibody in this condition? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tissue Transglutaminase 3 (ttg-3)

 

The patient's symptoms, including gastrointestinal complaints like malabsorption and diarrhea, combined with itchy skin lesions and histopathological findings of cryptitis and flattened villi, are indicative of dermatitis herpetiformis. This condition is closely associated with celiac disease, an autoimmune disorder triggered by gluten ingestion.

 

The specific antibody associated with dermatitis herpetiformis is tissue transglutaminase 3 (ttg-3). This antibody is primarily responsible for the characteristic skin lesions seen in dermatitis herpetiformis.

 

Other Option:

 

Option B. Anti-nuclear antibodies: Anti-nuclear antibodies (ANAs) are a group of autoantibodies that target components of the cell nucleus. They are commonly associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and other autoimmune conditions but are not related to celiac disease or dermatitis herpetiformis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of tissue transglutaminase 3 (ttg-3) antibodies is a hallmark of dermatitis herpetiformis, a condition associated with celiac disease. This autoimmune response is triggered by gluten ingestion and manifests with both gastrointestinal and cutaneous symptoms.

questions.text: A man on diuretics presents with weakness. An ECG was done which showed flat T waves and prominent U waves. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hypokalemia

 

Hypokalemia is a condition characterized by low potassium levels in the blood, which can occur in patients taking diuretics. Diuretics increase the excretion of potassium in the urine, leading to its depletion. The triad of ECG changes associated with hypokalemia are distinctive and include:

 

  1. Flattening of T waves: This is often the earliest change observed in hypokalemia.
  2. Prominent U waves: These waves become more visible as the potassium levels drop further.
  3. ST depression: This can occur in more severe cases of hypokalemia.

 

These ECG changes are due to the altered repolarization of the heart muscle cells caused by low potassium levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyperkalemia: Hyperkalemia, or high potassium levels, typically presents with different ECG changes, such as tall, peaked T waves, wide QRS complexes, and possibly absent P waves. These findings are not consistent with the patient's ECG.

 

Option C. Hypomagnesemia: While low magnesium can cause ECG changes and muscle weakness, the specific ECG findings in this case (flat T waves and prominent U waves) are more indicative of hypokalemia.

 

Option D. Hypernatremia: High sodium levels do not typically cause specific ECG changes. Severe hypernatremia might cause cerebral edema and nonspecific T wave inversions, but it does not lead to the characteristic ECG findings seen with hypokalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypokalemia is characterized by ECG changes such as flattened T waves, prominent U waves, and ST depression. It is commonly seen in patients on diuretics, and recognizing these ECG patterns is crucial for diagnosis and management.

questions.text: Shoulder dystocia is defined as delay in delivery of shoulders after delivery of head by? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 60 sec

 

Shoulder dystocia is technically defined as a delay in delivery of shoulders for more than 60 seconds after delivery of the head. 

 

Once the head is delivered and external rotation/restitution occurs, if the anterior shoulder doesn't deliver with gentle traction, maneuvers to relieve shoulder dystocia should be initiated immediately.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Shoulder dystocia has two definitions:

 

  1. Technical: Delay in shoulder delivery >60 seconds after head delivery
  2. Practical: Need for additional maneuvers beyond gentle traction to deliver shoulders after head delivery
  3. Turtle Sign: Seen in Shoulder dystocia

questions.text: A child presents with mental retardation, bone pain, and inability to walk. On fundoscopy examination, a cherry red spot is seen. There is no organomegaly. What is the most likely diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tay-Sachs disease

 

Tay-Sachs disease. The given clinical scenario, along with the fundoscopy image showing a macular cherry-red spot, indicates that the most likely diagnosis is Tay-Sachs disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Niemann-Pick disease: Niemann-Pick disease is another lysosomal storage disorder, but it often presents with hepatosplenomegaly (enlarged liver and spleen), which is not mentioned in the case. The cherry-red spot is not a typical feature of Niemann-Pick disease.

 

Option C. Hurler syndrome (mucopolysaccharidosis I), autosomal recessive condition that affects multiple organs. Enzyme deficient is α-L-Iduronidase. Presents usually at 6-24 months with clouded cornea, coarse facial features, joint stiffness, and skeletal dysplasia. Glaucoma, retinal degeneration, and nasal discharge are the other features. The condition is generally fatal.

 

Option D. Gaucher’s Disease presents with bone pain, hepatosplenomegaly, and trephine biopsy showing a cell with a characteristic crumpled tissue paper appearance. Mental Retardation is not seen.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: In a nuclear family, the oldest person is 67 years old, his wife is 59 years old. They have a son who is 30 years old, and the son’s wife is 27 years old. They also have a grandchild who is 5 years old. Calculate the dependency ratio for the family: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 66%

 

The dependency ratio is a measure used to assess the pressure on the productive population (those typically considered to be of working age, usually between 15 and 65 years old) from the non-productive population (those considered to be dependents, usually below 15 and above 65 years old).

 

DR is also known as Societal Dependency ratio (SDR)

 

The dependency ratio is calculated as:

 

 

In this scenario, the family consists of:

 

  • Dependents: 2 (A child of 5 years old and elderly 67 years old)
  • Working-age individuals (15-65 years): 3 (59 years old wife; 30 year old son and 27 year old Son’s wife)

 

Thus, the dependency ratio is calculated as:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dependency ratio is calculated as the number of dependents (below 15 years and above 65 years) divided by the number of working-age individuals (15-65 years), multiplied by 100.

 

Dependency ratio measures the ‘need for society to provide for its’ younger and older groups’

questions.text: DNA repair gene defect with increased risk of skin cancer is a feature of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Xeroderma pigmentosum

 

Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP) is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by a defect in the nucleotide excision repair (NER) gene. This defect impairs the body's ability to repair DNA damage caused by ultraviolet (UV) light, leading to a significantly increased risk of developing skin cancers, including basal cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, and melanoma, even at a young age.

 

Patients with xeroderma pigmentosum often exhibit extreme sensitivity to sunlight, with symptoms such as severe sunburn, freckling, and pigmentation changes. Over time, the accumulation of unrepaired DNA damage increases the likelihood of malignant transformations in skin cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bloom syndrome: Bloom syndrome is also associated with increased cancer risk, but it does not specifically present with a high risk of skin cancers due to UV sensitivity. It involves a different DNA repair pathway (homologous recombination repair) and is characterized by short stature, sun-sensitive skin changes, and a predisposition to various cancers.

 

Option C. Ataxia telangiectasia: Ataxia telangiectasia is a condition caused by mutations in the ATM gene, affecting the repair of DNA double-strand breaks. While it increases the risk of leukemia and lymphoma, it is not primarily associated with an increased risk of skin cancers due to UV sensitivity.

 

Option D. Lynch syndrome: Lynch syndrome (hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer) involves mutations in mismatch repair (MMR) genes and is associated with an increased risk of colorectal, endometrial, and other cancers, but not specifically skin cancers or UV-related cancers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Xeroderma pigmentosum is characterized by a defect in the Nucleotide Excision Repair (NER) gene, leading to increased sensitivity to UV light and a significantly elevated risk of developing skin cancers.

questions.text: A laborer's second child is brought to the OPD with a swollen belly and dull face. He has been fed rice water (rice milk) in his diet mostly. On investigations, the child is found to have low serum protein and low albumin. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kwashiorkor

 

The clinical presentation of a swollen belly and dull face in a child fed mostly rice water, along with findings of low serum protein and low albumin, is suggestive of Kwashiorkor.

 

Kwashiorkor is a form of severe acute malnutrition characterized by:

 

  • Edema: Resulting from hypoalbuminemia, which leads to fluid retention and swelling, especially in the abdomen.
  • Apathy and irritability: The child often appears listless and irritable.
  • Poor diet history: Often associated with diets low in protein, such as those predominantly consisting of carbohydrates like rice water.
  • Other symptoms: Growth retardation, muscle wasting, and skin and hair changes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Marasmus: Marasmus is another form of severe acute malnutrition but is characterized by severe wasting and absence of edema. Children with marasmus appear extremely thin with prominent ribs and have a "skin and bones" appearance.

 

Option C. Indian childhood cirrhosis: This is a chronic liver disease in children characterized by liver fibrosis and cirrhosis, but it does not typically present with the acute signs of protein malnutrition like Kwashiorkor.

 

Option D. Kawasaki disease: This is an acute febrile illness of unknown etiology that primarily affects children under 5 years of age and involves inflammation of blood vessels (vasculitis). It does not present with symptoms of malnutrition such as a swollen belly due to low protein intake.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kwashiorkor is characterized by edema, apathy, and growth retardation due to a diet deficient in protein, often with a swollen belly and low serum protein levels.

choices.text: Block release of acetylcholine from presynaptic terminal

questions.text: The mechanism of action of botulinum toxin is? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Block release of acetylcholine from presynaptic terminal

 

Explanation:

 

Botulinum toxin works by inhibiting the exocytosis of acetylcholine from presynaptic nerve terminals. In normal neurotransmission, acetylcholine is stored in vesicles in the presynaptic neuron and released when an action potential arrives. 

 

Botulinum toxin prevents the release of acetylcholine into the synaptic cleft, effectively blocking neuromuscular transmission and causing flaccid paralysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Block postsynaptic receptors of acetylcholine:  Incorrect. Botulinum toxin doesn't affect postsynaptic receptors. Drugs that block postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors include anticholinergic agents like atropine (for muscarinic receptors) or agents like curare (for nicotinic receptors).

 

Option B. Inhibit reuptake of acetylcholine: Incorrect. Unlike noradrenaline or serotonin, acetylcholine's action is not terminated by reuptake into the presynaptic neuron. Instead, it is hydrolyzed by acetylcholinesterase in the synaptic cleft. 

 

Option D. Inhibit acetylcholinesterase: Incorrect. Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors (like physostigmine, neostigmine, or pyridostigmine) increase acetylcholine levels by preventing its breakdown, resulting in enhanced cholinergic transmission. This mechanism is opposite to botulinum toxin's effect, which decreases cholinergic transmission.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Acetyl choline [Ach]

 

 

→Rate limiting step is: Uptake of choline

↓Parasympathetic activity

1. Hemicholinium

2. Vesamicol

3. Botulinum toxin

Ach Esterase Inhibitor→↑Parasympathetic activity

4. Physostigmine

questions.text: Which of the following is considered to be the best for the detection of Clostridium difficile? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glutamate dehydrogenase and toxin assay

 

A combination of glutamate dehydrogenase and toxin assay can be used for the detection of Clostridium difficile.

 

Clostridium difficile is a gram-positive anaerobic bacillus that causes Clostridioides (formerly Clostridium) difficile infection after ingestion of spores of the organism. The more severe form of the condition is known as pseudomembranous colitis (PMC). Enzyme immunoassay to detect glutamate dehydrogenase is less specific compared to toxin detection for diagnosis. So a combination of the two can be used for diagnostic confirmation.

 

The condition is most commonly associated with prolonged antimicrobial use, which interferes with the commensal colonic microflora. The most commonly implicated antibiotics are cephalosporins, ampicillin, and clindamycin. The spores are spread by contact with the feces of affected individuals or asymptomatic carriers.

 

The spores germinate in the small intestine and produce two toxins-toxin A (enterotoxin) and toxin B (cytotoxin). These interfere with the epithelial-cell barrier function and result in diarrhea and pseudomembrane formation. The pseudomembranes appear as small whitish-yellow plagues initially which later coalesce to involve the entire colon wall. It contains necrotic leukocytes, fibrin, and cellular debris. The anamnestic IgG response determines which patients develop the disease or remain asymptomatic.

 

Symptoms include diarrhea, fever, and abdominal pain. The diagnosis is based on a combination of clinical criteria and detection of toxin or the organism in stool samples. This can be done by nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) methods such as polymerase chain reaction (PC) or by culture.

 

Discontinuation of any ongoing antimicrobials and adequate hydration are general measures that are recommended. Oral fidaxomicin or vancomycin is the first-line treatment. Oral metronidazole can be used when these are not available.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aerobic culture of stool: C. difficile is an anaerobic bacterium, making aerobic culture inappropriate and ineffective for its cultivation.

 

Option C. Glutamate dehydrogenase assay alone: While sensitive, it lacks specificity for the detection of toxin-producing strains.

 

Option D. None of the above: There are effective methods, particularly the one described in option B.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For effective and accurate diagnosis of Clostridioides difficile infection, a combination of glutamate dehydrogenase and toxin assays is recommended. This approach ensures both the presence of the organism and its potential to cause disease through toxin production are assessed, guiding appropriate treatment and infection control measures.

questions.text: A patient presents with the complaint of inability to close the eye, drooling of saliva, and deviation of the angle of the mouth. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be affected? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Facial nerve

 

The given clinical features of inability to close the eye, drooling of saliva, and deviation of the angle of the mouth are suggestive of paralysis of the facial nerve.

 

Bell's palsy is defined as idiopathic, peripheral facial paralysis or paresis of acute onset.

 

Etiology –

 

  1. Viral infection  - herpes simplex, herpes zoster, EBV
  2. Vascular ischemia
  3. Heredity – narrow fallopian canal
  4. Autoimmune

 

Clinical features -

 

Onset is sudden. Patient is unable to close his eyes. On attempting to close the eye, the eyeball turns up and out (Bell phenomenon). Saliva dribbles from the angle of mouth. Face becomes asymmetrical. Tears flow down from the eye (epiphora). Pain in the ear may precede or accompany nerve paralysis. Some complain of noise intolerance (stapedial paralysis) or loss of taste (involvement of chorda tympani). Paralysis may be complete or incomplete. Bell palsy is recurrent in 3–10% of patients.

 

 

Bell's palsy is a diagnosis of exclusion. All other possible causes of facial paralysis should be ruled out by investigations.

 

Treatment of Bell's palsy -

 

  • Prednisolone is the drug of choice. If a patient reports within 1 week, the adult dose of prednisolone is 1 mg/kg/day divided into morning and evening doses for 5 days. Patient is seen on the fifth day. If paralysis is incomplete or is recovering, the dose is tapered during the next 5 days. If paralysis remains complete, the same dose is continued for another 10 days and thereafter tapered in next 5 days (total of 20 days).
  • Eye care to prevent keratitis
  • Analgesic for ear pain
  • Physiotherapy

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Trigeminal nerve: Mainly responsible for facial sensation, not motor control.

 

Option C. Oculomotor nerve: Primarily influences eye movement; paralysis typically results in ptosis and pupillary dilation, not facial drooping.

 

Option D. Glossopharyngeal nerve: Affects swallowing and taste sensations at the back of the tongue; does not cause facial drooping or affect eye closure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prompt recognition and treatment of facial nerve paralysis are crucial for improving outcomes and preventing permanent damage. Treatment primarily involves medication to reduce inflammation and supportive care, especially for eye protection.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 103, 104

questions.text: A G3P2L1NND1 presents at 37 weeks with previous 2 LSCS with primary active HSV. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) LSCS (Lower Segment Cesarean Section)


In a patient with a history of two previous lower segment cesarean sections (LSCS) and active primary herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection at 37 weeks of gestation, an elective LSCS is the safest approach. Active HSV infection is a contraindication to vaginal delivery due to the high risk of neonatal herpes transmission, which can lead to severe complications in the newborn. A classical cesarean (vertical incision on the upper uterus) is not indicated here because the LSCS provides a safer and more appropriate route without the additional risks associated with classical cesareans, such as increased bleeding and uterine rupture in future pregnancies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Classical cesarean: A classical cesarean involves a vertical incision on the upper uterine segment and is generally reserved for cases where lower segment access is challenging, such as in preterm deliveries or certain uterine anomalies. It is not warranted here and would increase future obstetric risks.

 

Option C.  VBAC (Vaginal Birth After Cesarean): VBAC is contraindicated in this case due to active HSV infection and the risk of neonatal transmission. Additionally, VBAC is not recommended after two previous cesareans, especially when other complications like active infection are present.

 

Option D. IOL (Induction of Labor): Inducing labor is contraindicated in patients with active HSV due to the risk of viral transmission to the baby during delivery. This approach would pose significant risks without any benefit in this clinical scenario.

 

Educational Objective:


Active herpes simplex virus infection during labor is an indication for a cesarean section to prevent neonatal transmission.

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient presents with abdominal pain, joint pain, and palpable purpura. His urine analysis shows RBC casts without any significant findings. The likely diagnosis is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IgA vasculitis

 

The clinical scenario described in the question is highly suggestive of IgA vasculitis, which was previously known as Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP). This condition is characterized by the involvement of multiple organs, including the gastrointestinal tract, joints, skin, and kidneys. The hallmark features of IgA vasculitis include:

 

  1. Gastrointestinal Involvement: Patients often present with abdominal pain, which may be due to vasculitis of the mesenteric vessels. In severe cases, it can lead to gastrointestinal bleeding.
  2. Joint Involvement: Arthralgia or arthritis is common, particularly affecting the knees and ankles.
  3. Skin Involvement: The presence of palpable purpura, typically on the lower extremities, is a key clinical feature. This is a type of non-thrombocytopenic purpura, indicating that the purpura is not due to low platelet counts.
  4. Renal Involvement: The presence of RBC casts in the urine analysis indicates glomerulonephritis, which is a common renal manifestation of IgA vasculitis.

 

IgA vasculitis is primarily an IgA-mediated small vessel vasculitis. The deposition of IgA-containing immune complexes in the small vessels leads to the inflammation and damage seen in the affected organs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Behcet disease: This condition is characterized by recurrent oral and genital ulcers, as well as uveitis. It does not typically present with the combination of symptoms described in this case, particularly the specific renal involvement with RBC casts.

 

Option B. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's): This is a form of vasculitis that typically involves the upper respiratory tract, lungs, and kidneys, but it does not present with palpable purpura or the same pattern of multi-organ involvement seen in IgA vasculitis.

 

Option D. SLE (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus): SLE can present with a wide variety of symptoms due to its multi-system involvement. However, the specific combination of abdominal pain, joint pain, palpable purpura, and RBC casts is more characteristic of IgA vasculitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IgA vasculitis, previously known as Henoch-Schönlein purpura, is characterized by abdominal pain, joint pain, palpable purpura, and renal involvement with RBC casts. It is an IgA-mediated small vessel vasculitis that commonly affects the skin, joints, gastrointestinal tract, and kidneys.

choices.text: MTP cannot be done as she has crossed 20 weeks
MTP can be done till 24 weeks
MTP can be done only if the mother's life is at risk
MTP can only be done if there is a substantial fetal anomaly

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl, a victim of rape, presents at 22 weeks for abortion. What advice will you give her? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B)  MTP can be done till 24 weeks

 

The MTP Act of 2021 in India allows for abortions b/w 20- 24 weeks in specific cases, including:

 

  • Rape or sexual assault: The girl in the question is a victim of rape, which falls under this category.
  • Risk to maternal life or Disability: If continuing the pregnancy poses a significant risk to the mother's health or life.
  • Substantial fetal anomaly: If the fetus has severe abnormalities incompatible with life or causing significant disability.
  • Minors: The girl is 14 years old, making her a minor, and the law provides special considerations for them.
  • Change in marital status or humanitarian grounds: These are additional situations where MTP may be considered up to 24 weeks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MTP cannot be done as she has crossed 20 weeks: This is incorrect. While the general limit for MTP is 20 weeks, certain circumstances, like rape, allow for MTP up to 24 weeks.

 

Option C. MTP can be done only if the mother's life is at risk: This is partially correct. While risk to the mother's life is a valid reason, it's not the only one. Rape is also a valid indication for MTP up to 24 weeks.

 

Option D. MTP can only be done if there is a substantial fetal anomaly: Again, this is partially correct. Substantial fetal anomaly is one reason, but rape is another valid reason for MTP up to 24 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In India, under the MTP Act of 2021:

questions.text: A 30-year-old man has come with history of lower back pain and stiffness since 3 months. His ESR and CRP levels are raised. He has mild restriction of chest movements and chest expansion is 3 cms. History of red eye is also there. The most likely diagnosis from amongst the following would be:(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ankylosing spondylitis

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

 

  • It is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy, a genetically determined generalized chronic inflammatory disease that primarily affects the axial skeleton (sacroiliac joint and spine) with variable involvement of root joints (shoulder and hip) and peripheral joints.
  • The involvement is an enthesopathy.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Males are affected more frequently than females.
    • Age of onset is between 15-25 years.
    • The initial symptom is usually dull pain, insidious in onset, felt deep in lower lumbar or gluteal region, accompanied by low back morning stiffness of up to few hour duration that improves with activity and returns following period of inactivity.
    • Question mark (?) posture is due to hyperkyphosis of thoracic spine and loss of lumbar lordosis.
    • Cervical spine involvement is usually late and show forward stooping and loss of extension and rotation.
    • Most serious complication of spinal disease is spinal fracture with even minor trauma.
    • The most common extra-articular manifestation is acute anterior uveitis (iridocyclitis) occurring in 30%.
    • Cataract and secondary glaucoma are common sequela.
    • Up to 60% of patients have inflammation of colon or ileum (mostly asymptomatic, only 5-10% develop IBD), 3rd degree heart block, cardiac dysfunction (Aortic incompetence), restrictive lung disease. IgA nephropathy, prostatitis and retroperitoneal fibrosis are other manifestations and may shorten life span.
       
  • Diagnostic criteria – Modified New York Criterion:
    • Essential criteria is definite radiographic sacroiliitis
    • Supporting criteria: one of these 3
      • Inflammatory back pain if 4/5 are present 
        1. Pain > 3 months
        2. < 40 years of age
        3. Insidious onset
        4. Improves with exercise
        5. Present at night
           
      • Limited chest expansion
      • Limited lumbar spine motion in both sagittal and frontal plane (schober test/modified schober test)
  • Etiology:
    • HLA B27 positive in more than 90 % cases
       
  • Radiographic findings:
    • Bamboo spine (bony ankyloses)
    • Squaring of vertebrae
    • Inter-spinous ligament calcification: dagger sign
    • Facet calcification of joints + inter spinous ligament Trolley Track Sign
    • Sclerosed vertebral edges: romanus sign

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paget’s disease. It is characterized by excessive disorganized bone turnover, that encompasses excessive osteoclastic activity initially followed by disorganized excessive new bone formation. Osteoclast appears larger and irregular whereas osteoblast are relatively normal. The new bone formed is abnormal, very vascular and larger (deforms and fractures) than preexisting bone which leads to cortical widening and contributes to the deformity.

 

 

The diagnostic histological feature is irregular area of lamellar bone fitting together like a jigsaw with randomly distributed cement lines. It either occurs in one bone (monostotic) or multiple bones (polyostotic).

 

 

Etiology is genetic infection by paramyxovirus (measles and respiratory syncytial virus). There is increased bone resorption accompanied by accelerated bone formation. Most people are asymptomatic. The sites most commonly involved are pelvis, tibia, followed by skull, spine, clavicle and femur. Affects men > 50 years more commonly. Pain is most common presenting symptom. Limb looks bent and feels thick, and skin is unduly warm due to high vascularity. Serum calcium and phosphate levels are usually normal. Increased marker of bone formation (e.g. S. alkaline phosphatase and S. osteocalcin). Increased markers of bone resorption. X-ray shows deformity, enlargement or expansion of bone with cortical thickening, coarsening of trabecular markings and lytic and sclerotic changes. Blade of grass lesion is seen.

 

 

Option B. Healed TB. The remineralization of the vertebral body, sharpening of disc margins, reduction of pre-/paravertebral shadows, and osseous/fibro-osseous fusion are signs of healing on X-rays but are unreliable. The remineralization can be appreciated after 2-3 months of ATT. Complete resolution of pre-/paravertebral collections, marrow edema of vertebra, and its replacement by fat/calcification on contrast MRI are observed with healing of spine TB. 

 

 

Serial radiographs showing progression of bony healing and complete resolution of cold abscess

 

Option C. DISH. Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis (DISH) is a spondyloarthropathy, also known as Forestier’s disease or ankylosing hyperostosis. It is a non-inflammatory disease, with the principal manifestation being calcification and ossification of spinal ligaments and the entheses. The whole spine may be involved, and bony ankyloses occurs, although the disc spaces and facet joints remain unaffected. In advanced stages, the disease may look like melted candle wax. The calcification and ossification is most common in the right side of the spine. The distinctive radiological feature of DISH is the continuous linear calcification along the anteromedial aspect of the thoracic spine. Morning stiffness is also noticed in around 2/3rd of patients. Increased incidence of dysphagia is also reported in some cases.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Presence of lower back pain and stiffness since months, raised levels of ESR and CRP, mild restriction of chest movements and chest expansion, with history of red eye are suggestive of presence of ankylosing spondylitis.

questions.text: Sympathetic ophthalmia is a consequence of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Penetrating ocular trauma

 

  • Sympathetic ophthalmia is a bilateral granulomatous panuveitis seen after a penetrating ocular trauma.
  • It can occur 2 weeks to 3 months after initial injury in 65% of cases, or following intraocular surgery.
