  • The injured eye is called ‘exciting eye’ and the fellow eye is called ‘sympathising eye’.
  • The clinical picture of iridocyclitis in the sympathising eye can be divided into two stages:
  • Prodromal stage: 
    • Earliest symptoms: sensitivity to light (photophobia) and transient indistinctness of near objects.
    • Signs: retrolental flare and cells, a few keratic precipitates (KPs), mild ciliary congestion, slight tenderness of the globe, fine vitreous haze, and occasional disc oedema.
  • Fully-developed stage: 
    • Typical signs and symptoms consistent with acute plastic iridocyclitis.
    • Anterior uveitis develops in both eyes, and multifocal choroidal infiltrates with sub-retinal pigment epithelium (RE) infiltrates corresponding to Dalen-Fuchs nodules can be seen in the mid-periphery of the fundus.
  • Treatment includes:
    • High-dose oral prednisolone for several months.
    • Immunosuppressives such as azathioprine, cyclosporine, and methotrexate for resistant cases or as steroid-sparing agents.
    • Enucleation of a severely injured eye with no visual potential within 2 weeks of injury to prevent the occurrence of sympathetic ophthalmia.

 

Differential diagnosis of Sympathetic Ophthalmia is Vogy-Koyanagi-Harada Disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blunt ocular trauma: typically does not cause sympathetic ophthalmia.

 

Option C. Chemical injury: primarily affects the ocular surface and cornea rather than causing granulomatous uveitis.

 

Option D. Urinary tract infection: is unrelated to ocular conditions and does not cause sympathetic ophthalmia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sympathetic ophthalmia is a preventable and treatable condition if diagnosed early and managed appropriately. Awareness of its presentation and prompt treatment can prevent severe bilateral vision loss.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl was washing her doll with shampoo containing rotenone. Her mother noticed her in an unconscious state. Which is inhibited by the above chemical? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) NADH dehydrogenase

 

Rotenone is a potent inhibitor of Complex I in the electron transport chain, which is also known as NADH dehydrogenase or NADH oxidoreductase. Complex I is responsible for transferring electrons from NADH to coenzyme Q (ubiquinone), a crucial step in cellular respiration and ATP production. By inhibiting Complex, I, rotenone disrupts the electron transport chain, leading to a significant reduction in ATP synthesis. This inhibition can result in decreased cellular energy and potential cellular damage, which explains the unconscious state observed in the child.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Succinate dehydrogenase: This enzyme is part of Complex II in the electron transport chain, which is not affected by rotenone. Complex II facilitates the transfer of electrons from succinate to coenzyme Q, bypassing Complex I, which is why rotenone does not inhibit this step.

 

Option C. Cytochrome C: Cytochrome C is a small heme protein that plays a role in electron transfer between Complex III and Complex IV of the electron transport chain. Rotenone does not affect Cytochrome C, as it acts upstream at Complex I.

 

Option D. Cytochrome oxidase: Also known as Complex IV, this enzyme is responsible for transferring electrons from Cytochrome C to oxygen, the final electron acceptor. Inhibitors of Complex IV include cyanide and carbon monoxide, not rotenone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rotenone specifically inhibits Complex I also known as NADH CoQ oxidoreductase (NADH dehydrogenase) in the electron transport chain, blocking electron flow and ATP production.

questions.text: A child presented with intellectual disability and hepatosplenomegaly. Bone marrow biopsy showed a “crumpled paper appearance.” What is your best diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glucocerebrosidase

 

The Ans. is Glucocerebrosidase, which is associated with Gaucher disease. Gaucher disease is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase. This deficiency leads to the accumulation of glucocerebroside within macrophages, resulting in cells that have a characteristic "crumpled paper" appearance when viewed under a microscope. The presence of these cells, along with symptoms like intellectual disability and hepatosplenomegaly, strongly suggests Gaucher disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. GALT enzyme: This enzyme is related to Galactosemia, a disorder of galactose metabolism. It does not present with a "crumpled paper appearance" in bone marrow biopsies, nor is it associated with the symptoms described in the question.

 

Option C. Pompe disease: Pompe disease is a glycogen storage disorder due to a deficiency of the enzyme acid alpha-glucosidase. It typically involves muscle weakness and cardiomegaly but does not produce the "crumpled paper" cells seen in bone marrow biopsies.

 

Option D. Niemann-Pick disease: This is another lysosomal storage disorder, but it is due to sphingomyelinase deficiency. The characteristic cells in Niemann-Pick disease have a "foamy" appearance, not the "crumpled paper" appearance seen in Gaucher disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "crumpled paper appearance" in bone marrow cells is a hallmark of Gaucher disease, caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase.

choices.text: Vaccinating pigs is helpful in disease control

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Japanese encephalitis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Man acts as the reservoir

 

Humans are the dead-end hosts for the Japanese encephalitis virus.

 

Japanese encephalitis is a viral infection caused by the Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), which belongs to the Flavivirus family.

 

Symptoms of Japanese encephalitis can range from mild, flu-like illness to severe neurological complications, such as high fever, headache, neck stiffness, disorientation, seizures, paralysis, and even coma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The disease is transmitted by Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui (common in India) species.

 

Option B. Herons act as reservoir hosts and pigs as amplifier hosts.

 

Option D. The control measures include mosquito control, locating piggeries away from the human dwellings and vaccinating pigs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the transmission dynamics of Japanese encephalitis is crucial for implementing effective control measures. While humans can become severely ill from JE, they do not play a significant role in the disease's transmission cycle, emphasizing the importance of controlling mosquito populations and managing amplifier hosts like pigs to reduce the incidence of this potentially deadly disease.

questions.text: A man presents with a history of dysuria and urethral discharge after having unprotected sexual intercourse. Gram-staining of the purulent discharge is seen in the following image. What is the treatment of choice for this infection? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ceftriaxone

 

The symptoms with the microscopic findings which shows gram-negative intracellular diplococci suggests infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae. The treatment of choice for the infection is ceftriaxone.

 

Treatment of Gonorrhoea –

 

  • Third generation cephalosporins – DOC for uncomplicated gonococcal infection - both the sexual partners should be treated.
  • Ceftriaxone (250 mg given IM, single dose)
  • Cefixime (400 mg given orally, single dose)
  • If coexisting chlamydial infection – azithromycin or doxycycline added.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Erythromycin and Option B. Azithromycin are macrolides, generally used for chlamydial infections or as a co-treatment when chlamydia is suspected alongside gonorrhea.

 

Option D. Penicillin G is no longer recommended as the primary treatment for gonorrhea due to widespread resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For uncomplicated gonorrhea, especially cases presenting with urethral discharge and identified intracellular gram-negative diplococci, Ceftriaxone remains the treatment of choice. This choice reflects current guidelines that prioritize efficacy and resistance profiles in managing sexually transmitted infections.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female labourer complains of soft, fluctuating swelling in front of the knee, directly over the patella. She reports discomfort and difficulty while moving her knee. MRI results confirm the findings. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Housemaid’s knee

 

  • Prepatellar bursitis or housemaid’s knee is the swelling and inflammation of the anterior knee bursa associated with pain with kneeling. 
  • The bursa affected lies anterior to patella. 
  • It occurs commonly due to excessive kneeling and also seen in wrestlers. 
  • On MRI, an oval shaped fluid-filled sac is seen anterior to the patella. 
  • The wall of the bursa may show increased thickness and irregularity.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subdermal abscess: A subdermal abscess in the knee is a pocket of pus that forms under the skin on the knee. It is usually caused by a bacterial infection. Symptoms of a subdermal abscess knee include pain, swelling, redness, and warmth in the knee. The abscess may also be visible as a raised, red bump on the skin.

 

 

Option C. Gout: Gout is an inflammatory arthropathy caused by long-standing hyperuricemia. Patients are usually asymptomatic for many years before developing symptoms and before radiographic evidence of disease. The first metatarsophalangeal joint is the most commonly involved joint. Involvement of the knee is not uncommon, but involvement of the patella is rare. MRI may demonstrate changes of gout arthritis including nodular thickening of the distal quadriceps tendon and erosion of the superior aspect of the patella. There can also be diffuse thickening of the prepatellar soft tissues , patellar tendon, and nodular thickening of the iliotibial band. 

 

 

Option D. Rheumatoid arthritis: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory autoimmune disease of unknown etiology that affects approximately 1% of the world population, with approximately 50% of adults being unable to work within 10 years of disease onset. The disease involves synovial joints and leads to progressive joint destruction. The knee joint is commonly involved in RA. Damage to the cartilage is associated with irreversible physical disability. The articular cartilage of the femoral condyles is destroyed early in the disease process, including roughening, softening, and fibrillation. MRI is the best non‐invasive modality to evaluate RA. It identifies synovial thickening, including inflammatory and fibrous proliferation, joint effusion, marginal erosions and subchondral cysts, periarticular soft tissue swelling, popliteal cysts, and tendon thickening. 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows an inflammation anterior to the patella. 
  • This is seen in prepatellar bursitis, also called housemaid’s knee.

questions.text: In modern obstetrics, which of the following investigations is used for monitoring the fetus of an Rh- negative sensitized mother? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) MCA doppler peak systolic velocity

 

Explanation:

 

  • A Doppler of the middle cerebral artery indirectly gives evidence of fetal anemia
  • An anemic fetus (For e.g. due to fetal red cell destruction in an Rh iso-immunized mother) will re-direct blood flow to more important organs like the brain.
  • This is reflected by an increased flow in the middle cerebral artery which can be measured by doing a Doppler of the MCA
  • In Rh immunized mothers, when indirect Coomb’s Test (ICT) titers rise above the critical titer of 1:16, then MCA doppler peak systolic velocity (PSV) is used for monitoring fetal anemia and development of hydrops in these babies.
  • MCA-PSV has replaced amniocentesis as it is a non-invasive test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Biophysical Profile: Biophysical Profile is a test of antepartum fetal assessment

 

Option B. Fetal blood sampling or Cordocentesis: This is done only when the fetal MCA doppler shows a peak systolic velocity of > 1.5 MoMs

 

Option C. Amnio-spectrometry: This is no longer done as it is an invasive method of measuring the amount of bilirubin in the amniotic fluid to determine the level of fetal anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MCA Doppler peak systolic velocity is used to monitor fetal anemia in Rh-negative sensitized mothers due to its non-invasive nature.

 

Ref: Page no 931, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A patient presented with headache, vomiting, and fever. Meningitis was suspected. While performing a lumbar puncture, which is the last structure you will pierce just before entering the lumbar cistern? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Arachnoid mater

 

The arachnoid mater is the last structure you will pierce while performing a lumbar puncture.

 

Layers pierced while performing lumbar puncture/spinal anesthesia (subarachnoid space) from outside to inside are:

 

  • Skin
  • Subcutaneous tissue
  • Supraspinous ligament
  • Interspinous ligament
  • Ligamentum flavum
  • Dura mater
  • Arachnoid mater

 

Upon piercing the arachnoid mater, you enter the subarachnoid space (lumbar cistern), where cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is collected during a lumbar puncture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ligamentum flavum: The ligamentum flavum is a strong ligament that connects the laminae of the vertebrae. It is pierced before the dura mater during a lumbar puncture.

 

Option B. Dura mater: The dura mater is a tough outer meningeal layer that is pierced before the arachnoid mater during a lumbar puncture.

 

Option D. Pia mater: The pia mater is the innermost meningeal layer that directly covers the spinal cord. It is not pierced during a lumbar puncture.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The arachnoid mater is the last structure pierced before entering the lumbar cistern during a lumbar puncture.

questions.text: What is the level of the lymph nodes marked in the image? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Level III

 

In the image, the arrow points to the middle portion of the sternocleidomastoid muscle, which corresponds to Level III cervical lymph nodes. Level III nodes are located around the middle third of the internal jugular vein and sternocleidomastoid muscle, between the level II and level IV nodes. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Level I: Incorrect as Level I includes submental (IA) and submandibular (IB) lymph nodes, located below the mandible and chin.

 

Option C. Level IV: Incorrect as Level IV nodes are located in the lower third of the sternocleidomastoid muscle, below the level indicated by the arrow.

 

Option D. Level II: Incorrect as Level II nodes are located in the upper third of the sternocleidomastoid muscle, above the level indicated by the arrow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Level III nodes are located around the middle third of the internal jugular vein and sternocleidomastoid muscle.
